questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the most common interstitial lung disease?
questions.explanation:

endothelium. The main pathology is fibrosis, mediated by TGF-ß and platelet-derived growth

questions.question:
Question 2: An 80-year-old woman was found to have a restrictive disease with reduced lung volumes on 
a pulmonary function test. A high-resolution CT of the thorax was done and is shown below. 
Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The above HRCT shows a honeycomb appearance of lung parenchyma due to interstitial 
fibrosis in a restrictive lung disorder that is suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). 
Inspiratory coarse crackles are not a feature of interstitial lung disease. Auscultating a patient with ILD will reveal bilateral basal end-inspiratory fine crackles also called 
velcro crackles or rales. Patients with interstitial lung disease usually present with a non-productive cough and 
breathlessness on exertion. Clubbing may be seen on examination, especially in advanced cases.

questions.question:
Question 3: 615 
Sold by @itachibot A 70-year-old woman presents with breathlessness on exertion and dry cough for 4 weeks. 
She has swollen joints and early morning stiffness for which she is on treatment for a few 
years. On auscultation, inspiratory fine crackles were heard. An HRCT was ordered and it 
showed bilateral, subpleural and basilar honeycombing pattern. PFT of the patient is likely to 
show which of the following patterns?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the HRCT findings are suggestive of interstitial lung disease 
(ILD). FEV1/FVC ratio >0.7 and decreased DLCO are likely to be seen in the PFT. A history of 
swollen joints and early morning stiffness hints at rheumatoid arthritis. It is associated with the 
usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern of ILD. In ILD, restrictive pattern is seen on pulmonary function test, which is characterized by: • Decreased total lung capacity (TLC) • Decreased forced vital capacity (FVC) • Decreased residual volumes (RV) • Decreased DLCO (diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide) • FEV1/FVC ratio - normal or increased, >0.7

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following is not a characteristic HRCT finding of usual interstitial pneumonia 
(UIP)?

options.a: Honeycombing and loss of lung architecture

questions.explanation:
Ground-glass opacities on HRCT are not a characteristic finding in UIP. Honeycombing, loss of lung architecture, traction bronchiectasis, and basilar subpleural reticular 
opacities are seen in UIP pattern of ILD on HRCT. 624 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following conditions is also known as Hamman-Rich syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) is also known as Hamman–Rich syndrome. AIP is a rare, idiopathic, fulminant interstitial lung disease (ILD) that is similar in presentation to 
ARDS. It is often preceded by a viral upper respiratory tract infection. Histologically, it shows diffuse alveolar damage. HRCT shows bilateral patchy, ground-glass 
opacities. Lung biopsy shows diffuse alveolar damage with hyaline formation.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 52-year-old woman presented with dyspnoea. General physical examination revealed 
deformity of the hand as shown below. There is restricted mobility in the small joints and loss 
of wrinkle lines on the facial skin. An HRCT of the thorax showed diffuse subpleural, 
symmetric, ground-glass opacities of the lungs. Which of the following histopathological 
finding is likely to be seen in the lung biopsy of this patient? 616 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing sclerodactyly suggestive of scleroderma along 
with the HRCT findings point to a diagnosis of non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP). It is 
characterized by homogeneous interstitial involvement. NSIP is often associated with connective tissue disease but can also be drug-induced. The 
common drugs implicated in NSIP are: • Bleomycin • Busulfan • Methotrexate • Amiodarone It usually affects middle-aged woman who have never smoked. There is uniformity of interstitial 
involvement across the biopsy section, and this may be predominantly cellular or fibrosing. HRCT 
shows homogenous involvement with symmetrical ground-glass opacities. Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) responds to steroids. Other treatment modalities 
include cytotoxic drugs like azathioprine or cyclophosphamide and also biologics like rituximab.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is not a smoking-related interstitial lung disease (ILD)?
questions.explanation:
Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is not related to smoking. It is usually seen in young females with tuberous sclerosis. LAM can lead to pneumothorax or 
chylous effusions. Pulmonary function testing usually reveals an obstructive or mixed obstructive-restrictive 
pattern. HRCT shows thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma. The smoking-related ILDs are: • DIP - Desquamating interstitial pneumonia. • RB-ILD - Respiratory bronchiolitis associated ILD. • LCH - Langerhans cell histiocytosis. 625 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A man presented with progressively worsening cough with sputum, breathlessness, easy 
fatiguability, and loss of appetite for 6 months. PFT was suggestive of a restrictive disorder. 
Trans-bronchial biopsy showed cells positive for CD1a and langerin (CD207). Which of the 
following is not a feature of this condition?

options.a: They may present with spontaneous pneumothorax
options.b: Cysts and nodules are seen on HRCT
options.c: It is a smoking related interstitial lung disease

questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). It is a 
smoking-related ILD that typically affects young adults. Smoking cessation leads to improvement 
in the condition. The specific immunohistochemical markers for LCH are CD1a and langerin (CD207). On electron 
microscopy, the presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is characteristic (as shown below). HRCT shows bilateral irregularly shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe. 
There is a risk of spontaneous pneumothorax in this condition due to cyst rupture.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following statements is false regarding pulmonary alveolar proteinosis?

options.a: Acquired due to antibodies formed against GM-CSF

questions.explanation:
Chunky, gelatinous, PAS-positive sputum is a feature of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP). PAP is a condition characterized by the accumulation of surfactants in alveoli and terminal 
airways. It can be due to impaired clearance or abnormal production of surfactants. PAP can be of three forms: • Primary (most common): There is impaired GM-CSF-dependent surfactant clearance by the 
alveolar macrophages. It can be due to: • Autoantibodies against GM-CSF (acquired/idiopathic/autoimmune PAP) • Mutation in GM-CSF receptors (hereditary PAP) • Secondary: There is a reduction in the number or ability of alveolar macrophages that causes 
impaired surfactant clearance. It can be due to: • Silicosis • Immunodeficiency disorders • Hematopoietic disorders and malignancies 626 
Sold by @itachibot • Congenital: It affects neonates and children. There is abnormal surfactant production due to 
mutation in the genes coding for: • Surfactant protein B • Surfactant protein C • ATP binding cassette protein member 3 About 30% of patients are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients can have persistent dry 
cough, progressive dyspnea, and pleuritic chest pain X- ray shows bilateral, diffuse opacities and HRCT shows a crazy-paving pattern (as shown below). 
The treatment is whole lung lavage.

questions.question: Question 10: Farmer’s lung is associated with which of the following organisms?
questions.explanation:
Farmer’s lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused due to exposure to mouldy hay, which 
contains thermophilic actinomycetes, principally Thermopolyspora polyspora.

questions.question:
Question 11: A daily-wage worker from the cement industry got a chest X-ray as a part of his routine health 
check-up. What could be the cause of the findings shown below? 618 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given X-ray shows irregular opacities, which appear to be pleural thickenings i.e., pleural 
plaques. The sign along with a history of working in the cement industry suggests a diagnosis 
of asbestosis. Workers of the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing 
asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first. The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis-related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques 
calcify resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on 
the X-ray. This is the “holly leaf sign”. 627 
Sold by @itachibot Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years). They present 
with cough and exertional dyspnoea. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in 
contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in 
both lung volumes and diffusing capacity. The image below shows thick plueral plaques.

questions.question:
Question 12: A woman has been working for a company that manufactures roofing sheets for 12 years, but 
the company does not provide her with personal protective equipment. Which of the 
following cancers is commonly seen in such individuals?
questions.explanation:
Workers in the roofing industry are exposed to asbestos. Lung cancer (of all histologic types) is the 
most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure. Smoking along with asbestos exposure multiplies the risk to a great extent. Cough and hemoptysis 
are common presentations. Pleural mesothelioma is the most specific cancer associated with asbestos exposure, but not the 
most common. Smoking does not seem to be associated with mesothelioma. Pleuritic chest pain 
or a mass on the radiographic image are common presentations.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which among the following is a common concern for a patient presenting with chronic dry 
cough, working in the granite mining industry?
questions.explanation:
Silicosis is a common concern for people working in granite mining industries. Silica is found in rock, granite, slate, and sandstone. People working in mining, stone cutting, 
sandblasting, glass and cement manufacturing, and quarrying are exposed to silica. The active 
molecule that causes silicosis is free silica or crystalline silica (quartz). Silicosis can present as: • Acute silicosis - due to heavy exposure in closed spaces and they manifest within 2 years. 628 
Sold by @itachibot • Chronic silicosis (simple silicosis) - due to long-term (10 to 30 years), less intense exposure. • Complicated silicosis- simple silicosis may progress to complicated silicosis that presents with 
chronic cough and progressive dyspnoea on exertion. Note: Silicosis is the most common pnemoconiosis in the world.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with an acute onset of dyspnoea. He tells 
you that he has been working in the sandblasting industry for about a year and the company 
does not provide personal protective equipment. He also gives a history of on and off dry 
cough. CT scan shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? 619 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
A history of working in the sandblasting industry for about a year without PPE suggests a heavy 
exposure to silica. This along with the CT finding of bilateral nodules, interstitial fibrosis, and 
crazy pavement pattern suggests a diagnosis of acute silicosis. Acute silicosis is seen rarely. It manifests within 2 years of heavy exposure. Common 
presentations are dyspnoea and hypoxemia. The X-ray may show diffuse miliary infiltrates or consolidation. HRCT may also show bilateral 
centrilobular nodules and ground-glass opacification. Bronchoalveolar lavage yields a 
PAS-positive milky white fluid.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 30-year-old man has recently started work in the stone cutting industry. The company 
provides him with a respirator mask but they do not use dust control measures. If he works in 
similar conditions for 20 more years, which of the following will you most likely see in his 
HRCT scan image?

options.b: Small round opacities in upper lobes
options.c: Thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma

questions.explanation:
In this scenario, the man works in the stone cutting industry, indicating exposure to silica. He is 
expected to have less intense, long term exposure owing to a few but substandard measures to 
control exposure to silica. Such individuals are more likely to develop simple silicosis. These 
patients are asymptomatic, and HRCT shows small round opacities in the upper lobes. This can progress to complicated silicosis. Here, the nodules coalesce and form masses leading to 
impairment of lung function. They present with chronic cough and progressive dyspnoea on 
exertion. This may progress further to cause progressive massive fibrosis. PFT shows a mixed obstructive and restrictive pattern. Calcification of hilar lymph nodes is seen 
in a few cases, called eggshell calcification. This is depicted in the image below. 629 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: A crazy pavement pattern is seen with acute silicosis. Option C: Thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma are seen in pulmonary 
lymphangiomyomatosis (LAM). Option D: Pleural plaques are seen in patients suffering from asbestosis.

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following pneumoconiosis is associated with an increased incidence of 
tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Silicosis is associated with an increased incidence of tuberculosis. Silica causes pulmonary alveolar macrophage dysfunction and hence, patients with silicosis have a 
higher risk of developing lung infections from organisms like M. Tuberculosis, atypical 
mycobacteria and fungi. Radiographic imaging of silicotuberculosis shows cavitation.

questions.question: Question 17: Choose the correct option with respect to Caplan’s syndrome.
questions.explanation:
Caplan's syndrome also called rheumatoid pneumoconiosis, is a combination of rheumatoid 
arthritis and pneumoconiosis. It manifests as pneumoconiotic nodules along with features of seropositive rheumatoid 
arthritis. Caplan syndrome was first described in coal miners and later in patients with silicosis 
too. Option C: Hilar adenopathy, polyarthritis, and erythema nodosum are characteristic of Lofgren 
syndrome. Option D: Arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis are characteristic of Reiter syndrome. 630 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A factory worker presents to the clinic with fever, tiredness, and a chronic dry cough. He says 
his symptoms are worst on the first day of the week, improve by the end of the week, and are 
almost non-existent over the weekends. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above characteristic pattern of symptoms is called Monday fever or Monday chest tightness 
and is due to byssinosis. Byssinosis is seen commonly in cotton factory workers due to cotton dust exposure. It is also 
caused due to flax, hemp, and jute dust. It is due to occupational hypersensitivity reaction with symptoms occurring (or recurring) on the 
first day of the workweek and diminishing by the weekend due to development of tolerance.

questions.question:
Question 19: Which interstitial lung disease is likely to be seen in a patient suffering from systemic 
sclerosis?
questions.explanation:
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) pattern of ILD is the most common pulmonary 
manifestation in systemic sclerosis. The CT scan of NSIP shows ground-glass opacities. It responds to steroids given along with 
azathioprine or cyclophosphamide. Other connective tissue diseases associated with ILD: • Rheumatoid arthritis • Sjögren syndrome • Dermatopolymyositis • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.question:
Question 20: A 45-year-old man who has worked as a miner for the past 25 years, comes to the OPD with 
complaints of dyspnoea and cough. Pulmonary function tests and a lung biopsy are done. The 
histopathology of the sample is shown below. Which type of emphysema can this condition 621 
Sold by @itachibot give rise to?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the microscopic image showing abundant black-colored pigment 
within the macrophages of lung parenchyma is characteristic of pulmonary anthracosis/coal 
worker's pneumoconiosis. It may give rise to centrilobular emphysema. The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages. They accumulate in the 
connective tissue along lymphatics or in lymphoid tissue along the bronchi or the hilum, which 
causes the blackening of the tissues. Aggregates of carbon dust are present as coal macules or 
nodules which consist of carbon-laden macrophages. It is commonly seen in people who work in environments where there is high air pollution with 
carbon particles, such as coal mines. It is usually benign and less than 10% of the cases develop 
progressive massive fibrosis which may lead to pulmonary dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension, 
and cor pulmonale. Coal workers may also develop emphysema or chronic bronchitis, 
independent of smoking. Unlike asbestosis, this condition does not predispose to cancer. 631 
Sold by @itachibot Bronchiectasis and Lung Abscess
